Award.AwardTitle: CNIC: US-Italy Research Project Development on Alpine Mountain Drainage Basin Response to Climatic Warming
Award.AbstractNarration:
Non-technical Abstract

This US-Italy research effort will catalyze a new collaboration to develop methods to identify how different river basins in the eastern Italian Alps respond to climate change. U.S. PI Sara Rathburn will work with three U.S. students and partners from the Free University of Bozen-Bolzano and the University of Milano-Bicocca to develop a project to study basins in the Adige River Valley selected for the valley's physical characteristics and the channel network that influences movement of water and sediment. The glaciers in the Italian Alps appear to be particularly prone to climate change due to their size and geographic location. Therefore, the team intends to use preliminary observations of drainage basin response to deglaciation to develop a quantitative index that can help identify particularly sensitive or resilient basins which may require different management under hazardous conditions. Changes to the amount of water and sediment delivered to mountain rivers influences the shape of river channels, and whether or not water is delivered efficiently and with minimal or abundant sediment to downstream communities. Given the importance of such glaciated headwater streams, this work may have implications for controlling the timing and amount of water available for agricultural, municipal, and hydropower needs. Findings may offer a useful comparison for similar basins in the U.S. Using historical documents of channel change that date to the Little Ice Age, over the last 250 years, and current field data on water and sediment discharge, the sensitivity index will then be tested for use in future projections. U.S. and Italian university students will participate in cooperative field research and should gain valuable early career experience with the practical implications of global climate change on water supply.

Technical Abstract

The US-Itaian collaboration is to establish methods to characterize response domains for drainage basins undergoing deglaciation in the Italian Alps to develop landscape sensitivity indices of past, present, and future changes in flow and sediment dynamics. Sensitivity indices will be based on valley geometry/channel morphologic changes and modern processes. Quantitative indices of drainage basin response to climate change are not widely available in current literature. The lack of quantitative indices limits the ability to identify particularly sensitive or resilient basins that require different management under changing climate. Research findings should advance our knowledge of how valley geometry and channel planform record changes in water and sediment discharge over the last 250 years, and quantitative measurements of current fluvial processes will be used as input to the conceptual model, with a final comparison based on projected climatic warming. Climate change poses myriad environmental and socieo-economic challenges, and research addressing landscape response has large and tangible benefits for communities weighing different hazard mitigation, adaption and resource protection options. U.S. and Italian students will collaborate on all phases of the research and gain exposure to complex, real-world environmental issues. Exposing students to collaborative research highlights the benefits of international teamwork in scientific inquiry and innovation to address future challenges of landscape change.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A USA-Italy research collaboration in the Italian Alps characterized response domains for drainage basins undergoing deglaciation. The response domains include: i) Areas above the Little Ice Age (LIA) limit, proglacial; ii) Above LIA limit, paraglacial (confined and unconfined valleys); and iii) Below LIA limit, postglacial (confined and unconfined) (Figure 1). We developed a landscape sensitivity index based on morphologic changes that occur if the influx ratio Q/Qs changes for past and present flow and sediment dynamics. Lithology, valley geometry, channel morphology and modern processes are taken into account. As far as we are aware, this is the first quantitative index of drainage basin response to climate change that is availalbe. Our results will help identify particularly sensitive or resilient basins that require different management under changing climate. 

Sediment connectivity modeling of four basins with differing lithology and aspect was completed to quantify relative sensitivity to deglaciation. The four basins include: i) Mazia; ii) Karlin, iii) Solda, iv) Trafoi within the Adige River valley (Figure 2). Results of the modeling indicate that mix lithology (carbonates and igenouse/metamorphic) basins are more highly connected in terms of sediment transport to the mouth than are monolighologic basins. Furthermore, legacy LIA landforms in some basins serve as barriers to connectivity. As such, bedrock lithology, glacial history and degree of sediment connectivity appear to be the dominant controls on drainage basin response to deglaciation within the Adige River valley. Total sediment loads from the Mazia and Solda basisn (unpublished data, F. Comiti) will be used to test the results of the connectivity modeling and the relative sensitivity indices for the study basins.

During the duration of this project, research by Dr. Francesco Comiti, one Italian collaborator, has focused on how valley geometry and channel planform record changes in water and sediment discharge over the last 250 years (since the Little Ice Age). In addition, his research lab is quantifying current flow and sediment transport in two of the four main study basins during snowmelt and glacial melt. 

Dr. Francesco Brardinoni, another Italian colleague, has completed detailed mapping of hillslope features in two research basins. In addition, Dr. Brardinoni brought a Mountain Geomorphology class to the site in summer 2015 and I assisted with a nature of science discussion and exercise as part of the broader impacts.

One abstract to a AGU was presented in Dec., 2015, two papers are in preparation (F. Comiti, 1st author PNAS; S. Rathburn 1st author ESPL), and ongoing work is continuing based on a proposal funded to F. Comiti. The Glaciers-to-Rivers Sediment Transfer in Alpine Basins (GLORI) funding to Comiti provided travel and accomoodations for Rathburn as a visiting professor to The Free University of Bozen-Bolzano from Sept. 1-16, 2017. We collected suspended and bedload data during glacial melt in the Solda Basin, gaged the flow, and completed new pebble counts at cross sections established in 2015 in all four basins. In adttion, my visit allowed for interactions with Comiti's students in the field and during my visiti to the university in Bolzano. Ongoing work is planned to include additional colleagues as part of the GLORI funding to Comiti that is an outgrowth of the NSF Rapid grant.

Three graduate students from Colorado State University were funded by this project, including two PhD students and one MS student. Two of the students assisted me with field work in Italy in 2015, and one student assisted with connectivity modeling. Two students were co-authors on the 2015 AGU abstract, and all three students are co-authors on the manuscripts in preparation.
